Hi Mark,

Thank you for reaching out. Below is a high-level overview of the workflow I generally follow when preparing and filing motions in our state courts. I have kept the points broad so that you can adapt them to the particulars of your matter and to any local-rule variations that may apply in your jurisdiction.

1. Preliminary Check-List
   • Confirm subject-matter and personal jurisdiction, standing, and ripeness.
   • Identify the governing rules (state civil-procedure, local rules, and any judge-specific preferences).

2. Drafting the Motion
   • Begin with a concise statement of the relief sought.
   • Lay out the relevant facts in numbered paragraphs, followed by the legal grounds and supporting authorities.
   • Keep citations short and use pinpoint references where possible.

3. Supporting Materials
   • Attach key exhibits and sworn statements that will not be in dispute (e.g., contracts, correspondence, or affidavits).
   • Add a proposed order for the court’s convenience.

4. Timing & Notice
   • Double-check the notice period and any page-limit requirements.
   • Calendar internal deadlines that allow for revisions and client sign-off before the filing window closes.

5. Filing & Service
   • File electronically whenever permitted; if filing in person, bring both a stamped copy for your records and an extra courtesy copy for chambers if required.
   • Serve all parties the same day as filing and include a certificate of service.

6. Hearing Preparation (if applicable)
   • As soon as the motion is filed, reserve a hearing date or follow local procedures for the court to set one.
   • Prepare a short outline for oral argument focusing on the dispositive points and likely questions.

7. Post-Filing Follow-Up
   • Monitor the docket for any briefing schedule or questions from the court.
   • Be ready to submit supplemental authority if new case law emerges while the motion is pending.

A few practical tips:
   • Use a standardized checklist to avoid missing formal requirements.
   • Keep exhibits under control; judges appreciate brevity.
   • Where rules are silent, a quick call to the clerk’s office often clarifies informal preferences.

I hope this provides a useful framework. Feel free to let me know if you would like to discuss any step in more detail.

Best regards,
Jane
